Purpose: Initializes the Angular application with root component and config
Internal Working: Creates the platform, initializes DI injector, renders root component, sets up providers
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Called once when the app loads in the browser

Purpose: Class instantiation and dependency injection
Internal Working: Called by Angular's DI system when creating an instance. Injects dependencies listed in parameters.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Used to inject services into components
Example Usage: constructor(private http: HttpClient, private router: Router) { }

Purpose: Initialization logic after Angular sets up data bindings
Internal Working: Called once after the first ngOnChanges(). Component inputs are available. Safe to make API calls.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Loading initial data from API when component is displayed

Purpose: Cleanup before component is destroyed
Internal Working: Called once before Angular destroys the component. Used to unsubscribe from Observables, clear timers.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Preventing memory leaks by unsubscribing from subscriptions

Purpose: React to @Input property changes
Internal Working: Called before ngOnInit and whenever one or more @Input properties change. Receives SimpleChanges object.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Parent passes new data to child component via @Input

Purpose: Logic after the component's view is fully initialized
Internal Working: Called once after the view (including child views) is initialized. DOM elements are available.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Initializing third-party libraries that need DOM elements

Purpose: Modern DI function to inject dependencies without constructor
Internal Working: Calls Angular's injector to resolve the dependency. Works in component class fields, guard functions, interceptor functions.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Injecting services in standalone components

Purpose: Create reactive state using Angular Signals
Internal Working: Creates a reactive primitive that notifies consumers when its value changes. Triggers change detection on update.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Managing component state reactively without RxJS
Example Usage: protected readonly title = signal('CustomerApp'); messages = signal<Message[]>([]);

Purpose: Make HTTP GET request to retrieve data
Internal Working: Creates an Observable that makes a GET request when subscribed. Returns Observable<T>.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Fetching customer list or single customer from backend API

Purpose: Make HTTP POST request to send data
Internal Working: Creates an Observable that makes a POST request with a body. Returns Observable<T>.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Creating a new customer or sending agent questions

Purpose: Make HTTP PUT request to update data
Internal Working: Creates an Observable that makes a PUT request with a body. Returns Observable<T>.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Updating existing customer details

Purpose: Make HTTP DELETE request to remove data
Internal Working: Creates an Observable that makes a DELETE request. Returns Observable<T>.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Deleting a customer record

Purpose: Subscribe to an Observable to receive emitted values
Internal Working: Starts execution of the Observable. Receives next, error, and complete callbacks. Returns Subscription.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Handling API responses in components

Purpose: Chain RxJS operators to transform Observable data
Internal Working: Creates a new Observable by applying operators sequentially. Each operator receives and returns an Observable.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Transforming API responses before they reach the component

Purpose: Transform each emitted value in the Observable stream
Internal Working: Applies a function to each value and emits the result. Does not change the number of emissions.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Converting backend VO objects to frontend Customer model

Purpose: Perform side effects without modifying the stream
Internal Working: Executes a function for each emission but passes the original value through unchanged.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Caching API response data and clearing cache after mutations

Purpose: Handle errors in the Observable stream
Internal Working: Catches errors from the source Observable and returns a new Observable or throws.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Providing fallback logic when primary API call fails

Purpose: Fail if Observable doesn't emit within time limit
Internal Working: Starts a timer when subscribed. If no emission within the specified time, throws a TimeoutError.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Setting max wait time for API response before using fallback

Purpose: Create an Observable from a static value
Internal Working: Emits the provided value(s) synchronously and then completes.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Providing fallback values in catchError handlers

Purpose: Emit a new value to all subscribers
Internal Working: Stores the value and sends it to all current subscribers. New subscribers get this value immediately.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Updating the customer cache after API call

Purpose: Get the current value synchronously
Internal Working: Returns the last emitted value without subscribing. Does not trigger any side effects.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Checking if cached data exists before making API call

Purpose: Set a new value for a signal
Internal Working: Replaces the current signal value and notifies all dependents to re-render.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Toggling loading state

Purpose: Update signal value based on current value
Internal Working: Receives a function that takes the current value and returns a new value. Notifies dependents.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Adding a new message to the messages array

Purpose: Create a FormGroup with controls and validators
Internal Working: Creates FormGroup instance with FormControls. Each key becomes a FormControl with initial value and validators.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Building reactive forms for data entry

Purpose: Update some form controls (not all)
Internal Working: Sets values for specified controls only, leaving others unchanged. Can suppress events with emitEvent option.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Populating form with data fetched from API
Example Usage: this.updateForm.patchValue({ fullName: customer.name, address: customer.address }, { emitEvent: false })

Purpose: Reset form to initial state
Internal Working: Clears all control values, resets validation state to pristine/untouched.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Clearing form after successful submission

Purpose: Mark all controls as touched to show validation errors
Internal Working: Recursively marks all controls as touched, triggering validation error display in template.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Showing all errors when user submits invalid form

Purpose: Check if all form controls pass validation
Internal Working: Returns true if all controls in the group have valid status. Computed from individual control validations.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Enabling/disabling submit button based on form validity

Purpose: Observable that emits on any form control change
Internal Working: Returns Observable<any> that emits the form's current value whenever any control changes.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Real-time interest calculation as user types

Purpose: Navigate to a route programmatically
Internal Working: Builds a URL from the provided commands, checks guards, resolves data, and activates the route.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Redirecting after form submission or navigating to edit page

Purpose: Get active navigation during route change
Internal Working: Returns the current Navigation object if navigation is in progress, null otherwise.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Checking navigation state for forceReload flag
Example Usage: const nav = this.router.getCurrentNavigation(); const reload = nav?.extras?.state?.['forceReload'];

Purpose: Access URL query parameters as Observable
Internal Working: Returns Observable<Params> that emits current query params and re-emits on change.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Reading customer ID from URL to load data

Purpose: Force immediate change detection for the component
Internal Working: Runs change detection synchronously for this component and its children. Required in zoneless mode.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Updating UI after async operations in zoneless Angular

Purpose: Flag component for checking in next detection cycle
Internal Working: Marks the component (and ancestors up to root) to be checked in the next change detection run.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Scheduling UI update after form value changes

Purpose: Filter array based on condition
Internal Working: Creates a new array with elements that pass the test function. Does not mutate original array.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Implementing client-side search/filter on customer list

Purpose: Transform each array element
Internal Working: Creates a new array with the results of calling a function on every element.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Converting backend VOs to frontend Customer objects

Purpose: Find first matching element in array
Internal Working: Returns the first element that satisfies the test function, or undefined if none found.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Finding a specific customer in the cached list by ID

Purpose: Extract a portion of an array
Internal Working: Returns a shallow copy of a portion of an array. Does not mutate the original.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Implementing client-side pagination

Purpose: Convert string to floating-point number
Internal Working: Parses a string argument and returns a floating-point number. Returns NaN if parsing fails.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Converting backend string numbers to JavaScript numbers

Purpose: Round up to nearest integer
Internal Working: Returns the smallest integer greater than or equal to a given number.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Calculating total number of pages for pagination

Purpose: Execute code after a delay
Internal Working: Schedules a function to run after the specified delay in milliseconds. Returns a timer ID.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Auto-clearing success messages and delayed navigation

Purpose: Cancel a scheduled setTimeout
Internal Working: Cancels a timeout previously established by setTimeout. Prevents the callback from executing.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Preventing duplicate timer when new operation starts before old timer fires

Purpose: Show browser confirmation dialog
Internal Working: Displays a modal dialog with OK/Cancel buttons. Returns true if OK clicked, false if Cancel.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Confirming destructive actions like customer deletion
Example Usage: if (confirm('Are you sure you want to delete?')) { this.deleteCustomer(id); }

Purpose: Output information to browser console
Internal Working: Writes a message to the web console. Supports string substitution and object inspection.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Debugging API responses and component lifecycle

Purpose: Convert JavaScript object to JSON string
Internal Working: Serializes an object to a JSON string. Handles nested objects, arrays, and primitives.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Storing user data in localStorage

Purpose: Configure Angular router with routes
Internal Working: Creates router providers including Router service, ActivatedRoute, RouterOutlet. Configures route matching.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Setting up application routing in standalone Angular

Purpose: Configure Angular HttpClient
Internal Working: Creates HttpClient providers. withFetch() enables Fetch API instead of XMLHttpRequest.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Setting up HTTP communication in standalone Angular

Purpose: Enable zoneless change detection
Internal Working: Removes Zone.js dependency. Change detection only runs on signal changes or manual trigger.
Real-Time Usage Scenario: Improving performance by eliminating Zone.js overhead
